properties.comment: These businesses either need to go or be substantially upgraded next to the daycare.

Unlikely for this area to have a reviving of industrial space and the community largely wants to see either light industrial or commercial or mixed use space. Would definitely encourage not keeping this industrial.
I believe this area needs to remain mixed-use commercial.

I’d propose we zone land in a radius around Marta heavy rail stops and the Beltline to be mixed-use medium density development. We need to have offices, apartments, townhomes, and retail nearby mass transit to efficiently add more residents. Land around Marta is underutilized at several stations, but the type of development on the Eastside beltline would make sense at each station and bus stop.
I would purpose a different plan for this area.  Morningside, beside Piedmont Park.

It seams that the definitions of Med Density & Low Density Residential have shifted - this area is currently RG-3 in Med Density however is .696 FAR on LUI table, and transitional height plane has kept new construction at 3-3.5 stories, there are no commercial uses - this section of Piedmont is part of Ansley Park's National Register of Historic Places district- RG3 was created specifically to preserve existing structures and allow houses to convert to multi-family. This has produced organically occuring afforbable housing and new constuction that is scaled with the neighborhood houses it is adjacent to.  The new Med Density is for 5+ stories, it would allow new construction that has a negative impact on existing structures and would encourage the demolition of the 20+ 100 year old building that are there now & the new ones would not be affordable. Based on new definitions RG1-RG-3 should be Low Density Res and RG-4 Medium Density Res

Build a small road. Connect these two halves of Grove Park. It is a legacy of racism that we still feel in the neighborhood. Often like a forgotten park of the community physically separate since segregation.

I am a little disappointed in the proposed development pattern for this area. I believe any neighborhood, especially with beltline proximity, should be ldr at minimum if not residential flex. There is a proposed beltine rail stop up the street at Metropolitan. Why limit the density here?

I understand that there is already some controversy over the proposed development and zoning of Amsterdam Walk (Amsterdam Ave & Monroe Drive).  Currently this area has not been highlighted to any zoning changes that would increase the area zone for high density commercial development.  I urge the city to keep it this way.  As a resident of the Morningside neighborhood, our streets are jam packed with cars all day & night.  As the traffic continues to increase on Monroe, Piedmont and Cheshire Bridge, more cars and commercial trucks cut through our neighborhood looking to avoid the bottlenecks.  As such, many of our streets are in terrible shape and it creates an unsafe environment for the residents as these vehicles often FAR exceed the speed limits.    Increasing commercial density, along with the plan to convert large sections of Monroe Drive from 4-lane to 3-lane, will only drive additional traffic into the neighborhood and negatively impact homeowners and residents.

The east side leading up to the neighboring oakhurst needs a dedicated bike path to get to the inner city and especially a way to connect with the belt line. It is extremely dangerous and anyone in this family friendly area is restricted from going there because of the lack of dedicated and protected bike lanes or pathways to do so. The current path signage and partial dedicated bike lanes in existing roadways is not sustainable to be rode or easily understood by adult riders.
With more e-bikes coming on the road everyday, it’s a great opportunity to plan for dedicated pathways not just adding to existing roadways, which doesn’t work for most and anyone with families.
Higher Density would be great!
Higher density here to match memorial drive!
this is a good cluster of areas that are useful to the neighborhood and good for attractions. it should also get higher zoning! reduce parking to zero if possible too!
this is a cool junction. it should be the gateway to the west since its already served by marta rail. make the speed limit 25mph and design roads to fit that! also make it more walkable.
Make Techwood Homes High-Density Mixed-Use. Seriously. There's no reason it shouldn't be. Especially when it comes to the city trying to meet affordable housing production goals.
Why is there low density around a BRT route actively under construction? Let people live near transit.
Homewood should be medium density, at minimum. Let people have housing. Especially near one of the largest universities in the state.
ALL industrial near / along the Beltline should be industrial flex.
It is actually insane to have low-density along both the current streetcar route, and the future extension.
WHY is this low-density? It's DIRECTLY adjacent to a MARTA station. What are we doing?
We're about to dump a LOT of money into BRT along Campbellton. This ENTIRE corridor should be medium-density, mixed use, at minimum.
This is such a mess of lot-by-lot micro-management that it kills any ability to just... let the city grow in a reasonable way. Make it all medium density and just be done with it.

This part of Capitol View and Capitol View Manor are relatively well connected to transit and adjacent to the Beltline. This area would really benefit from allowances and incentives for gentle density, like duplexes, triplexes, and four-plexes. This kind of housing would fit very well within the existing lot coverages and building sizes, keeping the feel of the neighborhood and taking advantage of new and existing developments.

Needs to allow for neighborhood commercial and ideally at least live work housing. Low density residential is insufficient at the rate of development in the area and demand for more local retail space.

This should NOT be zoned industrial! These properties are in the middle of a residential area and the designated zoning use is not even remotely comparable with the neighboring properties. PLEASE UPDATE THIS!

This Area should support greater desnity as these areas are places people frequent and are "gems" in the urban context off Atlanta. A lot of people from all over the city and metro come to little 5, Va-HI and Ponce Corridor. I understand not wanting to upset the character but not all development needs to be shiny new condos or 5 over 1s. Atlanta's old apartment housing stock like for example like 929 euclid avenue or 438 seminole avenue
Lines are not exact (problem getting the polygon to work) but the area roughly marked is the Brookwood Conservation Easement and should be greenspace ... not single family.

The BeltLine is an incredible development resource and amenity for creating walkable, sociable neighborhoods. I don't understand why single-family (and particularly large lot single-family) would be heavily prioritized here. I know about the legacy of Grant Park as an in-town suburb but this is hoarding some of the best public spaces in the city.

I walk through this area but also Edgewood all the time. Both neighborhoods have similar character but having the gentle density as in Edgewood provides a lot of affordable housing opportunities. Hopefully these opportunities are provided in a residential neighborhood right on the BeltLine.

Summerhill has opened up a nice local retail district with food and drink. However, the low density in the plan is going to make it hard to keep the businesses going outside the flood-famine cycle of Georgia State athletic events.
I would propose low density zoning as the current traffic patterns are already highly congested before a density increase.
This area on both the Beltline and the park should not be forced to be the least dense zoning. Its parcels should be allowed to be as dense as possible.
This area on the Beltline should be allowed to be far more dense.
The topography here is extremely steep which creates two different levels or the ability to make a fantastic apartment complex. This area should be allowed to be far more dense.

I think that Ansley Park is an area that is extremely low density and could better serve the community in its advantageous place near the Beltline, Midtown, and Transit lines with more multi-unit medium density housing.
I think that this area within transit distance of Midtown and the beltline could be residential rather than single family when considering the need for more housing.
Propose higher density to match existing duplex development pattern along 4 lane road here.  With no i485 project there is no need to prevent development here.
Zoning should match the Ponce corridor, and allow the transitional height plane to determine height limits
Allow high density development along Ponce and Beltline to balance with PCM
Rezone existing industrial use to allow for future density. Recommend MRC2
MRC2
Allow for increased density where these properties have been assembled under one owner. The City should take a stand on this parcel for future development.

I appreciate lower density here. However the zoning significantly reduces land values for improvements, resulting in pretty terrible infrastructure - rainbow paint aside. Would like to see some tactical urbanism or special projects to improve streetscape and bury power lines, consider the visibility of this intersection within the City.
Why is Trader Joes industrial? Make medium density to align with adjacent properties.
Consider a SPI District for the Ponce corridor, connecting Midtown to the Beltline. May be applicable for other arteries - North Ave, 14th, and 10th to West Midtown

As Metropolitan approaches the beltline and the center of town, we should be increasing density. If Medium Density is on the south side of langford parkway, it makes sense to increase this low-density mixed use designation to Medium Density mixed use.
There should be notes from NPU-X at the workshop at Goodwill Metropolitan that this should be industrial-flex.
Preemptively requesting Industrial Flex so that 50 years from now when Prologis sells the lot the community could have something useful.

This area should be upzoned and a prime location for building new housing, as the Beltline and especially the Streetcar East Extension run through here. Similarly, other Beltline-adjacent areas (up to 1/4 mile or so away) should also be upzoned for the same reason.

I believe that no area within about 5-7 miles of downtown should be zoned for single family, especially not large-lot single family. This will make it much easier to build housing near the core of the city.
There is a preschool here that is operating outside of it its permissible hours in the middle of low-density residential
Medium Density should be here, not high

The area along the neighborhood edge should be LDR. MDR is a wildly inappropriate proposal in that location and would particularly damage the residents currently living near those properties. As an Ansley Park resident and an architect with an understanding of zoning, I and every neighbor that I have explained the proposal to do not support LUI ratios that exceed the currently permitted ratios for RG3, and we do not support uses that are currently not permitted in the ordinance for RG3. If the city wants to pursue upzoning parcels adjacent to established neighborhoods, the city should feel obligated to proactively broadcast the idea to the impacted residents and consider the response. The current process relies on residents, many with no relevant expertise, to proactively engage and teach themselves about  zoning, which the city must know isn't going to happen at scale and only creates the illusion of community engagement.

Ansley Square should be LDMU, MDMU at the Kroger site, and MDMU at Amsterdam Walk. ABI and Zoning 2.0 do not share the same land use categories and neither has good definitions for the categories that they propose; consequently, no one in the community can really know what they are responding to.
The current ordinance transitional height plane limitations should be applied in any new new ordinance.
Amsterdam Walk cannot support high density.
The Streetcar East Extension is missing. It should be included and put back in.

the tran yard here is a major obstacle to traverse the west midtown area & makes westside paper development struggle.  there needs to be more bridges and pedestrian access connecting west midtown here. the city should work with the goat farm arts center to build bridges to connect westside paper area to the goat farm.

This is a lot of single-family only zoning right next to a large commercial area in Buckhead. It seems counterintuitive to stunt residential growth in an area that is becoming more and more desirable to people who want to live in Atlanta. It would be prudent to vary the zoning in this area.
High density across from single family is very inappropriate. Could you revise this so there is a step-up pattern in density and height from Avery Drive in historic Ansley Park?

I would propose this area to be industrial flex instead of industrial due to the apartments and businesses already present here, the mayors proposal for a MARTA station at this location, & the intersection of the beltline. Flex zoning would acknowledge the changing nature of the Armour district and allow it to grow naturally.
Timm Valley should be consistent with the rest of the neighborhood given its fully within Peachtree Park

This area is currently zoned R5 and is the same overlay as the rest of Peachtree Park on the current CDP maps.  The new maps need to keep this the same designation as the remainder of the R4 area.  It needs to be medium lot single family.  Many of the lots are actually being used as single family R4.  There is no egress to Piedmont and this is an internal street that needs to have the same CDP designation.
Timmy Valley should be MLSF to be consistent with the balance of the Peachtree Park neighborhood.

Timm Valley should be designated MLSF to be consistent with the rest of the Peachtree Park neighborhood. Timm Valley is only accessible from within the Peachtree Park neighborhood. Timm Valley is only accessible from within the Peachtree Park neighborhood. The designation as Low Density Residential is just one step down from Medium Density Residential with the possibility of a future upgrade that would be completely out of character with the greater Peachtree Park neighborhood.
This area is a significant traffic issue.  The road has a hill that drivers can't see over.  There is a church parking lot exit here, Mt. Olive, there are several near misses regularly.

I think this is welcome all park.  The park is beautiful but it needs more police protection.  Illicit activities happen here regularly, such drug comsumption and prostitution.  Because of this, the park is not a good place for families to be.
A nice park here, but it needs regular police presence.  It is not a good place for families because criminal actions.
This area has a significant drainage problem.
Traffic in this area is quite bad
This area has significant pavement destress.   It needs to be repaved.  Before repaving, please treat the cracking, that will help ensure the cracks don't return through the new pavement.
I would like to propose this area to allow for mixed use residential as it is right next to a MARTA station and should allow for some level of TOD (as exists right across the street)
This area should allow for Medium density mixed use, not industrial!
I would like to propose this area around the beltline to be high density residential or low density mixed use
I would like to propose this area as medium density residential or low density mixed use
I would like to propose this area as medium residential or low density mixed use
I would like to propose this area as medium residential or low density mixed use

As a resident of Peachtree Park, I do not believe that Timm Valley should be designated "Low Density Residential," as the City is using that term.  That "pattern" would be inconsistent with the street's current character and very much at odds with the larger neighborhood in which it sits.  It would bring additional traffic to streets that cannot safely accommodate it, and would doubtless lead to significant tree loss on currently-wooded slopes that are drained by vulnerable creeks (which would become urban runoff) and that serve as a buffer between the lots with wooded back lot lines.

Hello, I am a resident of Peachtree Park and am writing to urge thatTimm Valley should be designated MLSF to be consistent with the rest our neighborhood. 

Timm Valley is only accessible from within the Peachtree Park neighborhood. The designation as Low Density Residential is just one step down from Medium Density Residential with the possibility of a future upgrade that would be completely out of character with the greater Peachtree Park neighborhood and the environment we have created.

I would propose this stretch of Ponce de Leon Ave be designated High Density Mixed Use. It's currently a relative wasteland of parking lots when it lies directly between high-traffic areas (Midtown and the Eastside Beltline) and would benefit from the opportunity for more businesses to get in and revitalize the area.

This area should be changed to a Medium Density Residential area to match the area on Piedmont Ave NE. This neighborhood lies in the heart of Midtown, an incredibly up-and-coming area in the last couple decades. While I'm sure there's a lot of push from residents to avoid change, the area is highly desirable for proximity to work, kid's school, the park, and the beltline. To meet current and anticipated growth needs, more housing should be available close to the city centers.

I would propose Industrial Flex or Medium-High Density Mixed Use for the Armour Yards area, particularly if an infill Marta station is being considered here, with Beltline access, it could be much higher density than it is today.

I would propose medium density mixed use here. There are already shops and restaurants here so I don't think "medium lot single-family" makes sense for this area. Wouldn't that mean the city would like to see these shops and restaurants replaced with single family homes? I don't think anyone wants that.

Confused as to why Timm Valley has a different designation than the rest of the neighborhood. It should be designated MLSF as to be consistent with the rest of Peachtree Park. This is only one street in the neighborhood, and is only access from the Peachtree Park neighborhood. The proposed designation does not align with the character of the rest of Peachtree Park
Tim Valley should be deisgnated MLSF to be consistent with the rest of the neighborhood / surrounding MLSF areas
Enota Park - Open Space?
Beltline SA 2 MP proposes Mixed Industrial (industrial flex?)
Beltline SA 2 MP proposed Mixed Industrial (Industrial flex?)
Beltline SA 2 Master Plan proposed Mixed Industrial (Industrial flex?)
Please review the Beltline SA 2 master plan updated in 2021. Several proposed land use discrepancies in this area, adjacent to the corridor.
Betline SA 3 Master Plan updated, adopted in 2021. Several proposed land use changes are not reflected.
Beltline SA 4 MP, adopted in 2023, has different proposed FLU in this area. lower density MU proposed in this area. Please review.
Beltline SA 5 MP update, completed in 2021, recommends Medium density residential.
SA 5 MP proposed Medium Density Residential, not medium density mixed use.
Align with Beltline SA 5 proposed future land use recommendations.
SA 5 MP proposed Mixed Use medium density
SA 5 Master Plan shows medium density/low density residential here and not Mixed use.
Beltline Subarea 9 master plan proposed Medium density mixed use here.
Beltline Subarea 9 master plan proposes medium density residential. Plan adopted in October 2020.
SA 9 Master Plan proposes Open Space as the FLU in this area.
Beltline Subarea 9 master plan proposes mixed use high density in this area.
Beltline Subarea 10 Master Plan proposes Medium to high density residential for this area. This plan was adopted in October 2020.
Beltline Subarea 10 master plan propose mixed use medium to high density here.
Beltline Subarea 10 proposes mixed use medium to high density here.
Beltline Subarea 10 Master Plan proposes low density mixed use here.
Beltline SA 6 Master Plan (updated December 2024) recommends Low-Density Commercial for this area
SA 6 master plan recommends H-D residential here
SA 6 MP recommends H-D residential here.
SA 6 MP recommends M-D Mixed use here. (Ansley Mall)
SA 6 Master Plan recommends L-D mixed use here. (Ansley Square)
SA 6 master plan recommends open space here.
SA 6 master plan recommends M-D mixed use here.
SA 6 master plan recommends L-D mixed use here.
SA 6 master plan recommends L-D mixed use here. (Amsterdam Walk)
Beltline SA 6 master plan recommends H-D mixed use here.
SA 6 master plan recommends M-D mixed use here. This should reflect the Portman redevelopment that was approved.
SA 6 master plan recommends H-D mixed use here. Believe this reflects the Portman redevelopment.
SA 6 master plan recommends M-D mixed use.
SA 6 master plan recommends this parcel to be L-D mixed use.
Beltline Subarea 6 master plan recommends this area to be L-D mixed use.
SA 6 master plan recommends M-D mixed use here.
Sa 6 master plan recommends M-D residential here.
SA 6 master plan recommends H-D residential here.
SA 6 master plan recommends H-D residential here.
SA 6 master plan recommends SFR for this area (Large lot?)

Timm Valley should be designated MLSF to be consistent with the rest of the neighborhood." Further specifics and justifications are as follows--Timm Valley is only accessible from the Peachtree Park neighborhood. The designation as Low Density Residential is just one step down from Medium Density Residential with the possibility of a future upgrade that would be completely out of character with the greater Peachtree Park neighborhood.

Timm Valley should be designated MLSF to be consistent with the rest of Peachtree Park. Timm Valley is only accessible from this single-family neighborhood. The allowance duplexes is an historic CDP accident and mistake.

Timm Valley should be designated MLSF to be consistent with the rest of the neighborhood.
Timm Valley is only accessible from within the Peachtree Park neighborhood. 
The designation as Low Density Residential is just one step down from Medium Density Residential with the possibility of a future upgrade that would be completely out of character with the greater Peachtree Park neighborhood.
